image.altText: Kelly Bayer Rosmarin Senate hearing

props.synopsis: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin spent the morning being grilled in a Senate hearing. Here's a look at the key moments.

title.children: Compensation talks and triple-0 failures: Everything Optus's CEO said at the Senate inquiry

image.altText: Composite image of six victims of jumping castle tragedy with school signage as background

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian company is charged in relation to the Hillcrest jumping castle tragedy in 2021, in which six children died after a castle became airborne.

title.children: Hillcrest jumping castle operator charged over 2021 tragedy where six children died

image.altText: David McBride, wearing red glasses and looking off into the distance, outside the ACT court precinct.

props.synopsis: Former military lawyer David McBride gives up his fight against charges he broke the law by leaking classified material to journalists, by pleading guilty to stealing and unlawfully sharing secret military information.

title.children: Military lawyer David McBride pleads guilty to unlawfully sharing secret allegations of Australian war crimes

image.altText: A boy wearing a hoodie and sandles with a bandage on his face stands in the rubble of a destroyed house

props.synopsis: Leaflets are dropped into the towns of Bani Shubaila, Khuza'a, Abasan and al-Qarara in the eastern part of Khan Younis, the south's main city, telling civilians to head towards the nearest known shelter. Follow live.

title.children: Netanyahu speaks to US media as Israel tells civilians in southern Gaza to evacuate

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: US has 'deep concern' over strike on Jordan's field hospital in Gaza
Palestinine Red Crescent says its team is 'trapped' in Al-Ahli Hospital

image.altText: A police sign logo in Bordertown next to an Australian flag at half mast.

props.synopsis: The policeman shot dead in the line of duty, Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig, is being remembered as a "consummate" community officer of great "integrity" and "wisdom", as his death shocks the South Australian south-east community and the broader police force.

title.children: Tributes flow for officer killed in SA rural shooting in 'devastating day' for police

image.altText: A mural showing distorted faces covers the exterior second storey facade of businesses.

props.synopsis: A council in Melbourne's inner south-east will begin painting over a mural which has faced criticism for its resemblance to "highly offensive" anti-Semitic caricatures and tropes.

title.children: Mayor apologises for Melbourne mural after paintings attract criticism of anti-Semitism

image.altText: A composite image of Lilie James' white coffin with flowers on top, next to a picture of the woman in a graduation hat and cloak

props.synopsis: Hundreds of mourners attended a service for the 21-year-old, who was found dead inside St Andrew's Cathedral School last month.

title.children: 'We are so proud of you': Lilie James remembered at service with bright colours and florals

props.synopsis: Mitch Starc and Josh Hazlewood laid the platform with the ball, before Travis Head and David Warner did the job with the bat. Five quick hits as Australia ends South Africa's Cricket World Cup hopes in a low-scoring thriller at Eden Gardens.

title.children: Five quick hits — South Africa rues dropped chances and Aussie quicks strike early in World Cup blitz

image.altText: Protesters march along a street with one carrying a banner stating 'We're cactus mate' against an image of Australia burning

props.synopsis: Leaders in charge of Australia's response to climate change have told an energy summit the country can have "an even bigger impact" by helping the rest of the world decarbonise, as school students around the country fronted up for climate rallies.

title.children: 'It's as simple as that': Students rally nationwide calling for end to new coal and gas projects

image.altText: Anthony Albanese, wearing a suit, stands in front of a Qantas plane, with the logo visible.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been under attack from the Coalition and some sections of the media since he took office for the number of international trips he has taken. But how does he compare to other recent prime ministers?

title.children: How does Anthony Albanese's international travel stack up against other recent prime ministers?

image.altText: A woman's headshot

props.synopsis: Queensland University of Technology's vice-chancellor says the institution will move towards "inclusive suitability" rather than merit because "the workforce needs to reflect the students coming through".

title.children: This university won't be hiring based on 'merit' anymore — here's why

image.altText: Man climbing tree in forest

props.synopsis: The 61-metre karri trees have pegs all the way to the top for climbing but, after improvement works earlier this year, the upper platforms remain closed for further inspections.

title.children: WA government closes giant tree-climbing attraction for 12 months, sparking fears for tourism

image.altText: A middle-aged blonde woman speaks into a microphone in front of a dark, wood-panelled wall.

props.synopsis: Optus boss Kelly Bayer Rosmarin tells a Senate inquiry that 228 triple-0 calls were unable to be made during last week's outage, while the Australian share market falls slightly after Wall Street's recent rally comes to an end. Follow live.

title.children: Optus CEO tells Senate inquiry she has no plans to resign, has not had time to 'think about myself'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: RBA appoints former Turnbull staffer as Chief Communications Officer
That's it for the Optus outage inquiry in the Senate today
Final questions on small businesses and Optus company culture

image.altText: Sergeant Jason Doig shot in the line of duty

props.synopsis: The policeman killed in the line of duty in regional South Australia overnight has been named as Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig, a "highly respected" and experienced officer whose death has devastated the force.

title.children: Police officer shot dead, two people with gunshot wounds after incident on regional SA property

image.altText: A close up of the Messages app displaying on an iPad screen, with a small notification badge in its top right

props.synopsis: Issues between blue and green message bubbles could soon be a thing of the past, as Apple moves to adopt the RCS standard.

title.children: Apple announces surprise adoption of 'the new SMS' pushed by Google

image.altText: An illustration of Mark Hoppus, Travis Barker, and Tom DeLonge from Californian pop-punk band Blink-182

props.synopsis: How the Californian punk superstars went from cracking masturbation jokes to interrogating real emotions in one fell swoop.

title.children: 'It was like they were allowed to care': Blink-182's surprisingly mature self-titled album turns 20

image.altText: A pixelate image of a horse head on top of a bonnet.

props.synopsis: Pictures of the grim discovery have been circulating on social media and police are urging anyone with information to come forward.

title.children: Horse's head found dumped on bonnet of 4WD in WA

image.altText: VCE exam in progress sign

props.synopsis: Victorian Certificate of Education (VCE) students who were forced to take an amended Chinese language exam after it was accidentally given to a different class complain of a further stuff-up with the test.

title.children: 'The audio never showed up': Leaked VCE exam hit with further technical problem

image.altText: Di Sanh Sunny Duong wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Melbourne man "Sunny" Duong liked to boast about his connections and is a "big-noter", but never acted on behalf of the Chinese Communist Party to influence Australian politicians, his lawyer tells a foreign interference trial.

title.children: Businessman was 'big-noter' but never acted for Chinese government, foreign interference trial hears

image.altText: Khalid Abdalla wearing a button-up navy, white and yellow shirt, while Elizabeth Debicki wears a navy and white singlet

props.synopsis: Critics say the show took a "conservative approach" to her death, but that having Diana and Dodi Fayed appear to some characters after their death was "crass".

title.children: How much of season six of The Crown is real?

image.altText: Sean "Diddy" Combs wearing a white suit jacket.

props.synopsis: R&B vocalist Cassandra Ventura sues Sean "Diddy" Combs, accusing him of subjecting her to serial physical abuse.

title.children: Sean 'Diddy' Combs accused of sex trafficking, rape of ex-girlfriend

image.altText: a woman with short brown hair wearing a colourful dress looking serious

props.synopsis: The expert overseeing care of the Northern Territory's most vulnerable adults has explained why some face living under unnecessary guardianship orders.

title.children: NT public guardian warns some adults may be under guardianship with no need

image.altText: a soldier looks out at the port of gaza allegedly

props.synopsis: Video published by the IDF shows what it says is soldiers engaging in combat with Hamas militants in the port of Gaza.

title.children: Israeli Army says troops have taken 'operational control' of Gaza port

image.altText: Sticks and a makeshift cross stick out of the sand on a beach

props.synopsis: Police will travel to a remote West Australian island where shocked boat skippers found what they believe are recent burial sites, raising questions about the number of people who are dying unrecorded in Australian waters.

title.children: 'It was super eerie': Suspected human graves on WA island spark offshore mystery

image.altText: A man stands next to a fire truck

props.synopsis: A 75-year-old life-long volunteer firefighter who died while battling a bushfire burning in the New South Wales north-west has been remembered as a "committed life member" of the Rural Fire Service.

title.children: Captain Leo Fransen identified as volunteer firefighter who died while battling NSW blaze

image.altText: A black and white photograph of the North Sydney Olympic Pool next to the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

props.synopsis: Between 1939 and 1996 the government hired dozens of photographers to document Australian life. Now many of their works of intimate nature photography, striking architectural shots and captured everyday memories are displayed in a new exhibition.

title.children: Eighty years ago, the government hired photographers to capture a slice of everyday life. Here's what they produced
